title: 106_hr2261
content: The Act titled "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999" introduces a new section, SEC. 25B, which provides a credit for health insurance costs for previously uninsured individuals and those with COBRA coverage. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a credit for health insurance costs for individuals, allowing a credit of 60% of the amount paid for coverage for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. There is a dollar limitation based on monthly amounts for eligible months. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 offers a credit for health insurance costs, with a monthly limitation based on coverage type and eligibility criteria. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on eligibility criteria, including participation in group health plans. Eligibility is determined by the most recent month of eligibility for qualified health insurance. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 offers a credit for health insurance costs based on eligibility criteria, including participation in group health plans. For joint returns, a month must be eligible for both spouses. Certain other coverage, such as Medicare or military health programs, is not considered for the credit. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on eligibility criteria, including participation in specific health programs. For married individuals who do not file joint returns and do not live apart from their spouse, a special rule applies to limit the credit. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on eligibility criteria. For married individuals who do not file joint returns and do not live apart from their spouse, a special rule applies to limit the credit based on adjusted gross income. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on eligibility criteria. The credit is limited based on adjusted gross income, which is calculated by increasing adjusted gross income by any amount excluded from gross income under specific sections. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income. The credit amount is determined by specific dollar amounts, with rounding rules applied. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income. The applicable dollar amount for qualified health insurance coverage varies based on marital status and the number of individuals covered. Qualified health insurance is defined as insurance that constitutes medical care, excluding certain provisions. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 offers a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income. Qualified health insurance, as defined in the Act, excludes coverage provided under group health plans and certain other contracts with substantial benefits as excepted benefits. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income. Qualified health insurance excludes coverage from group health plans and certain contracts with substantial benefits as excepted benefits. Additionally, continuation coverage under COBRA is considered qualified health insurance, and special rules apply for deductions. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income. Special rules apply for deductions related to qualified health insurance, including coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income. Special rules apply for deductions related to qualified health insurance, including denial of credit to dependents and inflation adjustments for dollar amounts after 2000. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income, with special rules for deductions related to qualified health insurance. The cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year is determined by substituting 'calendar year 1999' for 'calendar year 1992'. Amounts adjusted under this provision are rounded to the next lowest multiple of $100. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 provides a credit for health insurance costs based on adjusted gross income, with special rules for deductions related to qualified health insurance. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on costs of qualified health insurance. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This deduction allows individuals to deduct a percentage of their health insurance expenses for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The applicable percentage is determined based on a table provided in the legislation. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The applicable percentage for deducting health insurance expenses is based on a table provided in the legislation, starting at 60% in 2000 and increasing to 100% in 2004 and thereafter. A special rule applies for individuals not covered by an employer's group health plan. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A special rule applies for individuals not covered by an employer's group health plan, allowing for a higher deduction percentage if certain conditions are met. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction applies to individuals not covered by an employer's group health plan, with specific conditions for a higher deduction percentage. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs for individuals not covered by an employer's group health plan. The deduction is subject to special rules regarding earned income limitations. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is limited by the taxpayer's earned income, excluding amounts considered under subsection (a). Special rules apply, such as coordination with medical deductions and the deduction not being allowed for self-employment tax purposes. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is limited by the taxpayer's earned income, excluding amounts considered under subsection (a). Special rules apply, such as coordination with medical deductions and the deduction not being allowed for self-employment tax purposes. Conforming amendments specify eligible long-term care premiums paid for qualified long-term care insurance contracts covering the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is limited by the taxpayer's earned income, excluding amounts considered under subsection (a). Special rules apply, such as coordination with medical deductions and the deduction not being allowed for self-employment tax purposes. Amendments specify eligible long-term care premiums paid for qualified long-term care insurance contracts covering the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999.
